components.text: Many students may not have practical experience so have questions and concerns; being on placement can be significantly different to academic assignments. Frequently asked questions and concerns include:

list_elements.text: How do I complete my placement documentation?

components.text: If you are worried about completing any official documents speak to Academic Personal Tutor, Learning Support Tutor or contact the Disability team for support

list_elements.text: Who will I talk to about any issues once on placement?

components.text: Your educator will be willing to address any concerns you may have, also you could contact the visiting tutor or the disability tem on campus.

list_elements.text: How will I meet all the competencies?

components.text: If you are worried about your ability to meet any competencies, speak to your Learning Support tutor.

list_elements.text: What if I don’t like my placement?

components.text: Have an open mind and a positive attitude towards the placement, try to assess objectively what you may not like. You may find the work and learning on placement challenging but if you find you do not like working in that environment you may want to consider why you chose the profession. Speak to your academic tutor or contact the disability team on campus to arrange an appointment.

list_elements.text: How do I manage assignments and placement commitments/ shifts?

components.text: You will be given a typical shift, this will basically correspond to the type of shifts you should expect when you clarify. There are absence policies in the hand books, if you are unable to make a shift, if it expected that you inform your educator and all relevant personnel in a professional manner.

list_elements.text: Good time keeping

components.text: You are expected to be on time and present throughout the placement period. If you have challenges getting to and from the placement let your educator or mentor know your travel arrangements, they may be able to advise you about alternate routes or more suitable public transport links. Always plan to arrive at work 15 – 30 minutes before your shift begins and consider heavy traffic, parking problems and delays around hospitals.

list_elements.text: Finances

components.text: It will be a good opportunity to review your finances, Ensure you have enough money saved as you may not be able to work during a placement. Some students save up for placements during the summer, ensuring they have the extra cash to cover any moving costs or transportation. Make a list of all the things you need and have a sensible financial plan ready. Note that student bursaries are no longer available for the majority of health and social care students in the England. Some students with disabilities may be able to get some financial help, see 1 and 2 for further information.

list_elements.text: Feeling isolated

components.text: Having peers on the same placement is good practice. It is important you plan to have a normal social life while you are on placement.

Your placement will have various requirements for you to meet. It is useful to be aware of these requirements through reading your placement handbook and the competencies. Direct any questions about these requirements to your personal tutor, learning support tutor or course leader before the placement begins. Having understanding before starting will help you feel prepared and ready.
If you have any questions during placement you can contact the disabilities team by phone or email:
The disabilities team has lots of experience working with students who have disabilities. They are happy to provide you with advice, tips and will support you with your concerns.

There are many myths about placements. Some students are worried about working in non-campus setting and being introduced to the world of work. But placements are learning environments too. Students have to acknowledge that the learning is taking place in a “real world” clinical health delivery space, as such the rules of engagement are different. Ensure you clearly understand the purpose of your placement, what you want to achieve and the level of your commitment. Do your best to learn as much as you can and demonstrate to show educators and mentors that you are dedicated student who has a lot to learn. The educators and mentors would like to know your scope of practice and will be happy to help you when you make mistakes

sections.subtitle: Receiving Support from Disabilities Support Team

components.subtitle: The Disabilities Team
components.text: The disabilities team can support you through offering advice, tips and through teaching study skills to contribute to success whilst on placement e.g. strategies to learn and remember new vocabulary.

If you have any questions about preparing for your placement and would like some tips and advice from the disability advisors or specialist tutors, you can book an appointment with the disabilities Team. To book an appointment, follow the link below:

Reasonable adjustments are changes to the work environment that allow people with disability to work safely and productively. Under the Equal Opportunity Act 2010, 'disability' includes: physical, psychological or neurological disease or disorder. illness, whether temporary or permanent.
A student with a disability can legally request RA when they are going on placement. You will be supported by the Learning Support Tutor to put these in place.
It is your responsibility to think about what you will need and articulate these clearly to the placement.
You can get help on this from the Learning Support Tutor and the Disability Office.
If you have a disability that will have an impact on your work or behaviour ensure you inform the relevant people prior to the placement.
If you require support or additional needs, you will need to inform your educator. It is better you do this before the placement.

sections.subtitle: Now what? Consider what you will need

list_elements.text: How will you get to and from work? Look up transport links and plan for possible delays or cancellations if you are using public transport. Ask about parking and possible tips from your educator or other staff.
Do you know the shifts you will be working?
Ensure you are meeting the requirements and competencies. You can break them down into SMART goals.
Small, measurable, achievable, relevant and timebound
Your educator needs your feedback to support you. Listen carefully to what the educator/mentor wants you to achieve and feel free to discuss your scope of practice and how you learn best.
You can always ask for support. If you feel you need support contact the disability team, your learning support tutor or your educator/mentor.

sections.subtitle: What if I think of something after?

components.text: It is OK if you think of any questions after you’ve made pre-placement contact, after you’ve completed documentation or after you’ve met with support staff.

list_elements.text: If you have questions you can contact your LST by email.
You could also make further contact with your practice educator by phone or make second pre-placement contact.

components.text: For further tips and advice, make an appointment or email the disabilities team:

sections.subtitle: Discuss with PT/LST about pre placement contact

components.text: It is your responsibility as a student to contact the placement before you begin. If you need time to discuss any reasonable adjustments, you could ask the LST to support you.

Educators and mentors are usually busy doing their day job; however, they will be happy to discuss your learning needs with you. You could decide if you want to visit the placement before you begin or make contact via telephone.
It is good practice to contact the placement before you start. You can do this by telephone or arrange a pre placement visit.

Many placement sites are busy environments and it may be difficult to arrange a pre placement visit. If you will benefit from a preplacement visit, ensure you arrange this in good time so that the team has time to arrange it and have a brief chat with you. A pre placement visit does not have to be long. Do your best to make a list of what you want to say and be as concise and clear as possible.

sections.subtitle: If you cannot arrange a preplacement visit

components.text: You can make a list of your needs and goals and give this to your educator when you begin your placement and have your first meeting to discuss the placement
Thought bubble - To implement - Do you need a real time visit or a telephone call?

If you need reasonable adjustments make sure they are all agreed and documented. If you are unclear about anything, you could speak to the LST about what has been agreed. Watch the videos at the following link to get a better idea about what additional needs means.

components.text: It is important you have all the information you need before your placement. There are a lot of resources to enable you plan and prepare adequately for your placement. Most placements are successful, as such the likelihood that you will have an unsuccessful placement is slim.
Ensure you have everything you need so you can be confident you will be at your best when you arrive at the placement.
